course.course_name: Urban Environmental Planning, Parts 1 and 2
course.course_description: The goal of this course is to provide the ideas and information necessary to integrate environmental viability and sustainable development with other primary concerns of urban planners and public health practitioners, namely, social justice, human rights, environmental integrity, and health in the broadest sense, to include quality of life. This course will cover the major concepts of public health research and practice relevant to urban planning by providing an historical basis for the topics discussed, as well as current applications. The unifying theme for each topic will be the past, current, and future state of affairs from both an urban planning and public health perspective. No special disciplinary background is required, but students are expected to think critically and to incorporate their unique perspectives into the classroom discussions.

course.course_name: Law and Social Science
course.course_description: Examines the influence of social science research on procedure, evidence and substantive legal areas, and the interactions of substantive law, legal analysis, social science findings, and social science method. From the origins of the use of social science in law to Daubert; the complex issues that arise when social science is used to determine facts, to make or change laws; and ways to establish a context or framework for deciding specific cases. Uses of social sciences in planning litigation. Case studies of specific substantive areas of the law of the uses of social science methods to establish evidence, and case presentations.

course.course_name: Introduction To Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_description: Students learn to (1) discuss major theoretical and methodological perspectives in the social sciences and explain how they apply to various public health issues and problems; (2) describe social, behavioral, cultural, and historical factors that contribute to health; (3) discuss the importance of the social sciences in the prevention and management of public health problems; and (4) apply social science theory in the implementation or evaluation of public health interventions. Health promotion and disease prevention, AIDS, social inequalities, race and racism, health disparities across various ethnic groups, social networks and personal resources, and mental health.

course.course_name: Introduction To Clinical Medicine and Public Health
course.course_description: Overview of medical diseases and the various organ systems of the human body; pathophysiology, diagnostic criteria, and treatment approaches to diseases. Emphasis on the relationship of disease and its impact on public health. Infectious diseases (TB, AIDS), cardiovascular disease, pediatrics, psychiatric illness, alcohol and substance abuse, Basic medical terminology; nurse, M.D., and social worker work as a team within the hospital organization.

course.course_name: Homelessness: Public Health and Public Policy
course.course_description: The changing causes and manifestations of homelessness in 20th-century U.S.; emphasis on the postwar period. The available data in each period; contemporary accounts of the problem and proposals to remedy it. The enduring distinction between the deserving and undeserving poor and the changes in the expression of that tradition; archival research or policy analysis.

course.course_name: Tutorial: Public Health and Disability Policy
course.course_description: Examines the dilemmas of national disability policy. Highlights include a new chapter on Healthy people with Disabilities in Healthy People 2010, the document that conveys U.S. public health priorities; the World Health Organizations new International Classification of Functioning and Disability; the Americans With Disabilities Act; recent legislation on disability, work and health insurance; and research resources, e.g., National Health Interview Survey on Disability.

course.course_name: Preventive Health Behavior
course.course_description: Overview of health promotion and disease prevention in public health. Examines the contribution of health behaviors to morbidity and mortality; leading theories of health behavior change. Emphasis on assessing the role of community-based health promotion programs in public health. Trends in health promotion; the influence of social factors on health behaviors; the use of ecological models in designing health promotion programs; individual, group, and community level theories of health promotion and behavior change; approaches to needs assessment and planning; community collaborations in health promotion; challenges to evaluating community health promotion programs; efficacy of community-level interventions; and the role of Healthy People 2010 in setting health objectives for the nation. First in the sequence of SMS courses required for all Health Promotion and Disease Prevention track students.

course.course_name: Preventive Medicine and Public Health
course.course_description: The scientific basis of preventive medicine; practical applications in public health. Primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease and cancer, the role of nutrition in health promotion and disease prevention, the report of the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force; less traditional concerns of preventive medicine such as injuries, violence, suicide, and substance abuse; future trends.

course.course_name: Health Promotion/Disease Prevention Seminar Series
course.course_description: Presentations focus on practices used in the field of health promotion and ongoing research in the field.  Speakers include faculty, guests, and post and predoctoral students.  (Co-sponsored by the Harlem Center for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention and the NYC Department of Health/Columbia Mailman School of Public Health Preventive Medicine Residency Program.)

course.course_name: Overview of Long-Term Health Care Services In Aging
course.course_description: An overview of community-based and institutional services within the systems of long-term care (LTC), informal supports, and the role nonprofit consumer organizations can play in articulating deficits in the systems and advocating for change. Emphasis on Alzheimer's disease as a prototypical chronic illness. Guest lecturers in medicine, research, bioethics, advocacy, law, social work, nursing, and nonprofit organizations. Site visits arranged to community-based and institutional settings.

course.course_name: Introduction To Theory and Research On Interpersonal Violence
course.course_description: (Designed for M.P.H. students) Introduction to the definitions, patterns, and explanations of violence in the U.S. Throughout modern history, concerns about violence have often mirrored the emergence and decline of social problems. In the U.S. explanations of violence have implicated culture, political economy, social inequality, social class, race, gender, genes, mental illness, drugs and technology. Survey of the literatures on etiology, the epidemiology of violence, research methods, and comparative studies. Intervention and prevention strategies.

course.course_name: The Use of Large-Scale National Health Care Data Sets
course.course_description: An overview of research methodology utilizing major, publicly accessible, large-scale health care and social demographic data sets, including federal, state and local level resources covered: (1) variable identifications and definitions; (2) record layouts; (3) data set size and analysis restrictions; (4) variable strengths and weaknesses; (5) research protocol submissions required by agencies for access to confidential data; and, (6) data handling methods. These data permit a wide range of research questions to be addressed. Presentation of current and recently completed research activities and projects under development. Analysis of data at levels ranging from the individual patient to the national population.

course.course_name: Tutorials In Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_description: Primarily for students who wish to acquire further knowledge and research skills in areas of special interest. Individual or small group reading tutorials or guided independent research.

course.course_name: Overview of Geriatrics and Gerontology
course.course_description: Topics include the demography and epidemiology of aging and biological, social, medical, psychological, and psychiatric factors that influence the aging process, the problems that develop and the manner of treating and caring for the aged.

course.course_name: Interactive Health Communication
course.course_description: Provides an introduction to use of informatics-based approaches to create and deliver educational and behavioral interventions. Topics include theories related to client-health care provider communication using electronic media; privacy, confidentiality, and security issues related to Internet communication; design of targeted and tailored health messages for underserved populations; evaluating health care content on the World Wide Web. Students who complete this course will be able to describe major issues associated with client-health care provider communication using electronic media including the Internet, critically analyze health care content on the World Wide Web, critically examine barriers associated with use of informatics-based approaches for underserved populations including ethnic minorities and persons living in rural settings, differentiate between targeted, personalized, and tailored approaches for electronic health communication, design and implement tailored health communication message for use in a subgroup of an underserved population taking into account issues such as readability and cultural beliefs. Requirements include developing a tailored web-based application.

course.course_name: Promoting Teamwork Through Interdisciplinary Collaboration
course.course_description: This course has an experiential focus where the class becomes a team in a supportive environment to assess one's ability and that of others in the class to affect the functioning of the team. Emphasis is on problem-solving about team development, management and process issues related to health and social service systems along the continuum of care. Participants learn to facilitate cohesive team functioning and diagnose the etiology of malfunctioning teams.

course.course_name: Graduate Colloquium In Race and Public Health In the Twentieth-Century United States
course.course_description: Offers varying interpretations of the history of race and public health in the United States. Students will examine issues dealing with epidemic disease, public health policy, and urban politics, among others. The texts selected in no way represent the full spectrum of this history -- the field has grown rapidly in the past decade. Rather than a "comprehensive knowledge" of race and public health in the United States, a grasp of historical methods will be gained through the readings. Students will end the semester well prepared to tackle problems pertaining not only to public health, but to larger issues as well.

course.course_name: Social Dimensions of Aging
course.course_description: Social theories of aging, developmental changes, cultural perspectives and intergenerational relationships. The aging worker, housing, ageism and health care for the elderly. The social construction of the aging experience through examination of models of psychosocial health in old age, and in-depth revew of current research investigations focusing on bereavement in the elderly, health status of older adults, long-term care needs and dependency relationships.

course.course_name: Child and Family Policy, I and II
course.course_description: Year-long seminar on child and family policy. Team taught by faculty from Social Work, Public Health, and Teachers College. Provides a multi-disciplinary perspective on child and family policies. The varying approaches to child policy by different social and behavioral sciences (history, sociology, demography, economics, political science, and developmental psychology), family law, as well as a cross-national perspective. Social problem situations involving children and their families. Specific child and family policy domains, the current major research developments in each domain, and the relevant policy debate.
course.prerequisites: some background in U.S. social policy and either child development or child policy.

course.course_name: Assessment of Health and Function In Aging
course.course_description: Review of strategies and instruments for the assessment and eventual diagnosis of mental, physical and social problems of older people. Emphasis on the underlying principles of these instruments in relation to various disorders. Videotapes of interviews with older people are used for developing participants' skills in the use of assessment tools.

course.course_name: Introduction To Medical Sociology
course.course_description: Required for all sociomedical sciences students; open to others with the instructor’s permission. The application of sociological concepts and methods to the study of health and health care. Social factors in conceptions of health and illness; in relation to health, health-related behavior, and the use of health care services; and in the organization of health care.

course.course_name: Seminar In Evaluation of Health Programs
course.course_description: Review of the basic principles and methods of evaluation in public health. Critical analysis of existing evaluation studies.
course.prerequisites: Biostatistics P6103 or P6104; and for all Health Promotion and Disease Prevention (HPDP) track students, P6727, Preventive Health Behavior and P8772, Planning and Implementation of Health Promotion Programs.
course.course_instructors_full: J. Moon Howard, M. Millery, S. Staff

course.course_name: Sexuality, Health Issues, and Public Policy, I
course.course_description: How have public health, medicine, and policy addressed sexual/health issues in the past century? Examines historical and contemporary examples of health issues with sexual dimentions (STDs, eugenics, birth control, and sex education) in order to understand the formation of policy. The growth of public health efforts paralleled major changes in sexuality and gender in the U.S., England, and Europe, as well as increasing social and political obilizations around sexual issues and problems. Analyzes the complex interplay between empirical data and scientific knowledge, professional and governmental definitions of health problems, and the larger cultural frameworks used to understand sexuality.

course.course_name: Current Readings In Sexuality and Gender
course.course_description: Analysis of new articles and books focusing on sexuality, gender, and health. Readings drawn from social sciences and public health, reflecting current issues and controversies in method and theory.

course.course_name: Seminar In Sexuality, Gender, Health and Human Rights
course.course_points_notes: Students must fill out application form in order to obtain permission. The form is posted at: cpmcnet.columbia.edu/dept/gender/seminar.htm.
course.course_points_cooked: 3 pts. Students must fill out application form in order to obtain permission. The form is posted at: cpmcnet.columbia.edu/dept/gender/seminar.htm.
course.course_description: Examines recent scholarship regarding sexuality, and explores ways of integrating its empirical findings and theoretical challenges with work on gender, health and human rights. Builds on developments evident since the U.N. conferences in Cairo and Beijing, as well as the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Analysis of new work on sexuality in light of current practical issues raised by policy intervention, public health programs, and grass-roots organizing. Analysis of contemporary case studies in order to identify significant achievements, limitations, and challenges posed by current approaches and programs, in domestic and international settings. Promotes dialogue and exchange between academic, activist, and advocacy work.
course.prerequisites: previous course work or work experience in at least two of the following areas--sexuality gender, health, and human rights--and instructor's permission

course.course_name: Sexuality, Health Issues and Public Policy, II
course.course_description: The social, historical, cultural, and scientific factors influencing contemporary policy issues and controversies regarding sexual/health issues. Builds on P6721. Analysis of contemporary case studies in order to identify the significant elements in the formulation of policy. The complex interplay between empirical data and scientific knowledge, professional and governmental definitions of health problems, and the larger cultural frameworks employed to understand sexuality.

course.course_name: Women and Health
course.course_description: Health issues pertaining to historical and contemporary experiences of women. The conceptualization and measurement of health and illness in social science research the significance of gender in receiving and providing health care services in the U.S.
course.prerequisites: core courses in epidemiology, biostatistics, and sociomedical sciences, and instructor's permission

course.course_name: Critical Topics In Human Sexuality Across the Life Course
course.course_description: Major theories of human sexuality and recent developments in sexuality research; Methodological and assessment issues in the study of sexuality; the ways in which sexuality research and principles inform public health efforts promoting sexual health. Emphasizes a developmental approach to human sexuality across the life course and a biopsychosocial model as a basis for understanding sexuality and health.

course.course_name: Public Health and Aging
course.course_description: An overview of the aged population, both in the United States and internationally, and its increasing relevance for public health planning and policy.  Five major topics are covered: 1) "age" in its biologic, demographic, and epidemiologic dimensions; 2) aspects of the health of the aged, evident in assessment of health status, function, cognition, and health service use; 3) the formal, "semi-formal," and informal components of long-term care for elders with chronic disease; 4) minority aging; and 5) policy issues related to an aging population.  Lectures and guest presentations.  Students are required to prepare a class presentation on a set of readings including a written critique of a paper, complete a midterm exam, and write a final paper on an agreed upon topic.

course.course_name: Historiography: History of Medicine and Public Health
course.course_description: Classic texts and concepts in the field of history of public health and medicine cover. (1) changing historical interpretations; (2) historical methods, quantitative and qualitative; (3) the use of history in the formation and analysis of public policy. Each section team is taught by two faculty members whose scholarship and current research relate to the historical concepts and methodologies that are the focus of the session.

course.course_name: Urban Space and Health
course.course_description: This course is designed to explore the interrelationship of space and health, particularly in cities. Begins with the thesis, proposed by Jane Jacobs and others, that the system of the city is an engine for economic development, creativity and civilization. The strength of the engine is a test of the composition of the city, and alterations in the composition of the city can augment its ability to serve as an engine. Sometimes people change cities in ways that make them healthier for their residents--sometimes they make things worse. This process of city change/health change is the explicit focus of this course: 1) to ensure that public health practitioners are aware of the changes in the city being made by others, so they can weigh in on potential health effects, and 2) to give students of public health some ideas of the ways in which they might themselves tinker with cities to make them more supportive of residents' health.

course.course_name: Privacy, the State, and Epidemic Disease: Policy Conflicts In Aids and Tuberculosis
course.course_description: The ethical and political controversies that have emerged in efforts to control tuberculosis and AIDS. The paradigm of disease prevention that emerged in response to tuberculosis (case finding, case reporting, treatment, and quarantine) examined in the context of AIDS, where concerns about the right to privacy have been given such salience. Screening, reporting by name, criminalization of transmission, discrimination, and access to care.

course.course_name: Masters Essay In Sociomedical Sciences
History of Sexual Health Promotion In 20th Century New York City
course.course_description: This course will examine a representative selection of major health issues pertaining to sexuality that were the focus of public health promotion campaigns in 20th century New York City.  Drawing upon assigned readings, lectures, and individual assignments that intersect history, policy and research, students will analyze how these campaigns -- and the resulting public policy -- have been shaped by social, ethical and political factors. The course will examine four “case study” health issues (masturbation, prostitution, venereal diseases, and contraception) to demonstrate how they exemplified the historical evolution of sexual health promotion within the emerging public health field.  Involving political leaders, health practitioners and self-proclaimed reformers, these campaigns were designed to elucidate, intervene, and resolve pressing health issues regarding sexuality.  During the early and mid-20th century, these health issues, implemented as public policy, became a primary arena in which racist policies were institutionalized and the vehicle by which a repressive acculturation process was the 'sin qua non' experience for the large immigrant populations arriving in the US.   Our analyses will be placed within the context of 20th century New York City -- a primary venue of large waves of immigration as well as numerous public health campaigns, ensuing moral panics and political struggles around sexual health issues.  The course will conclude with an analysis of three current public health issues that evoke these early public health interventions and promotional efforts: adolescent sexuality, HIV/AIDS, and sexuality education.  Students will be able to critically assess and evaluate these historical frameworks and practices of public health promotion regarding sexuality in order to apply insights gained to their work in the public health field.

course.course_name: Promoting Sexual Health
course.course_description: Sexuality has long been a public health concern, although this concern has been primarily limited to the field of reproductive health.  In recent years, however, due in large part to the AIDS epidemic, public health researchers, policy makers and providers have taken up the issues of sexual health more generally.  Sexual health is now considered a critical component of people’s well-being and a plethora of theoretical and applied initiatives have been and are being developed around the world to promote the sexual health.  It is a critical and innovative time for the field and important debates have begun to emerge over what defines sexual health and what a public health approach to the promotion of sexual health should look like.  This course offers a broad overview of theoretical foundations and empirically informed intervention strategies aimed at promoting sexual health.  Specific topics include theoretical foundations for the promotion of sexual health, including cognitive-behavioral, cultural and structural approaches; and the tension between population and community-based intervention strategies.  In addition, the course includes detailed reviews of existing intervention models conducted in both U.S. and developing country settings, thus providing opportunities to examine how particular theoretical affiliation, specific program and policy guidelines, and the characteristics of different communities inform the conceptualization, intervention and evaluation of strategies to promote sexual health.

course.course_name: Culture, Sexuality and Hiv/Aids
course.course_description: Overview of the historical development of social science research on sexuality and sexual health. Contemporary development of social science research on sexuality and sexual health, particularly during the 1960s and 70s (but prior to the HIV/AIDS epidemic), in disciplines such as anthropology, sociology and social psychology; significant changes in sexuality research following the emergence of AIDS, exploring the increasing engagement between social science research and public health programming as well as the constitution of sexual health as a new field of specialization.

course.course_name: Drugs and Society
course.course_description: Drug abuse as a health and social problem. Historical and cross-cultural perspectives; the concept of addiction; patterns, trends, antecedents and consequences in drug use and abuse--the epidemiology of tobacco, alcohol, heroin, marijuana, and psychotropic drugs; psychosocial perspectives; drug abuse and crime; the social costs of drug abuse; the evaluation of treatment and prevention strategies.

course.course_name: Global Aids Policy
course.course_description: A broad overview of the social, political, and economic factors shaping the global HIV/AIDS epidemic, and of the policy responses that the epidemic has generated in different settings. The international and intergovernmental response to the epidemic, focusing on the extent to which HIV/AIDS can be understood as a kind of test case in international health, illuminating both the possibilities and the limitations of the international system, in responding to perceived health emergencies.

course.course_name: Tutorial: Advanced Issues In Aids Research
course.course_description: Current issues and problems in AIDS research from the perspectives of both the social sciences and the biological sciences. Students examine critically and discuss research journal articles in their particular field of study. More than 1 point may be earned by satisfactorily completing a written project (for example, a research paper or grant proposal) on AIDS by the end of the term.

course.course_name: Women, Children and Aids
course.course_description: The HIV/AIDS epidemic has had a devastating impact on women and children, and intervention efforts have often been stymied by a host of social, familial, and environmental factors that place women and children at risk for HIV disease in the first place.  In the US, these include poverty, substance abuse, urban stress and violence, ethnic and gender disparities in access to health care, multigenerational patterns of substance abuse, trauma, and mental health problems, and the break up of the family.  Internationally, economic, political, and cultural factors converge to place millions of women at risk for HIV/AIDS.  Focusing on women and children living with HIV disease in the US, this course will provide an overview of the epidemiology of HIV in women and children, the health and mental health effects of living with HIV disease either as an infected person or an "affected person," and the psychosocial, familial, ethical, and public health issues that have emerged over the course of the HIV/AIDS epidemic for women and children.  How some of these issues apply internationally and to intervention research will be considered as topics of discussion.  Several ethical and public health issues will be discussed and analyzed, including: a) reproductive decisions in HIV+ women and HIV testing of newborns, and b) decision making about disclosure of maternal and child HIV status. Barriers to health care, as well as intervention models developed to address the health and mental health needs of women and children, will also be presented and evaluated.

course.course_name: Race, Culture and Genetics
course.course_description: Genetic information has become an integral part of public health practice through genetic testing for disease and susceptibility to disease, as well as through interventions such as newborn screening for sickle cell disease, cystic fibrosis and phenylketonuria  The mapping and sequencing of the human genome and the growing recognition that many common chronic diseases result from multifactorial interactions between genetic and environmental factors can only increase the influence of genetics and genomics on public health.  Yet the ethical, legal and social aspects of the genetics revolution occur in a historical context in which the past uses of genetics paradigms have been harmful for racial and ethnic minority populations.  This class will examine the sociohistorical construction of race and the place of racial and ethnic issues in genetics.  We will then use our knowledge of the relationship between racial matters and genetics to analyze present practices in public health genetics.

course.course_name: Organizational and Community Linkages
course.course_description: Development of the optimal principles by which organizations and communities link to each other. Principles of administrative structure (e.g., hospitals, nursing homes, HMO's) and their affect on the nature of linkages. The conceptualization of the various barriers to effective health communication between organizations and communities, drawing on health data, and other areas.

course.course_name: Informal Social Networks
course.course_description: The unique role that informal networks play in a modern industrial society as contrasted to formal organizations. The specific roles played by spouses, kin, friends, neighbors, volunteers, and various other weak tie groups. Ideal states of each of these groups; major variations; and their impact on social functioning and health.

course.course_name: The Social History of American Medicine
course.course_description: Major themes, approaches, and interpretations of the history of medicine. The impact of culture upon medicine and medicine upon culture. Focus on the U.S. in the 19th and 20th centuries, with frequent references to European developments.

course.course_name: Health-Related Social Movement In Comparative Perspective
course.course_description: This course addresses the role of social movements in making social change in public health and medical care.  Students will acquire the tools with which to analyze systematically the circumstances under which health-related social movements emerge, elements of movement organization and ideology, determinants of movements’ relation to the state, and circumstances associated with movement failure and success.  Comparative cross-national studies of health-related social movements will be used to illuminate the role of the nation-state in shaping opportunities for movements to emerge and the form they take.  This is a seminar course.  There is substantial outside reading, and students are expected to actively participate.  Performance will be evaluated based on in-class presentations (30%), participation in class discussion (20%), and a final research paper (50%).

course.course_name: Health Communications, Social Marketing and the Media
course.course_description: Increasingly, communication avenues, such as mass media and the internet, play an essential role in the public's health perceptions, knowledge and behaviors. Topics include social marketing theories, audience segmentation concepts, media advocacy techniques, public relations practices, mass media participation, message design and public campaign execution, formative research and evaluation. Lecturers include producers from major networks, writers from the New York Post and Times, publicists from major PR firms and advertising agencies, leaders from the Ad Council, and officials from local non-profit and NYC Health Department media campaigns. Students groups design a social marketing campaign around a public health issue of current importance.

course.course_name: Emerging Topics in Urbanism and Community Health
course.course_description: As the world population has become concentrated in cities, the well-being of population groups is increasingly determined by the structure and function of the urban area.  Communities within cities are stratified by wealth, culture, race/ethnicity, and other factors, which determine the flow of resources and opportunities.  The health of a given community is thus intimately tied to the modes of distrubution of resources that exist within the city, as well as those that situate the individual city within the local, national and global matrix of urban areas.  This seminar is part of a one-credit series required for urbanism students over three semesters.  Part I is intended as an introduction into the study of the ecology of cities.  Seminar topics will include concepts utilized in the study of the ecology of cities, case studies, and emerging issues related to urbanism.  In part II, students will utilize concepts of urbanism and the study of the ecology of cities as they relate to the planning of spaces that make healthy cities.  Seminar topics will include the study of contagious housing destruction, planned shrinkage and their links to health.  In part III, second year students will take a leadership role by leading in-class discussion.   Students taking part III will work on outlining their Master's Integrative Projects.
course.course_instructors_expected: M. Fullilove, R. Fullilove, L. Hernandez-Cordero
course.course_instructors_full: L. Hernandez-Cordero, M. Fullilove, R. Fullilove

course.course_name: Seminar On Gay and Lesbian Issues In Public Health
course.course_description: Theoretical and methodological tools for conducting public health research, designing public health interventions, or developing health programs for lesbian and gay populations. The social construction of homosexuality; lesbian/gay world and culture; the social psychology and health effect of prejudice, stigma, and stereotyping; homophobia and heterosexism; antigay violence; gay/lesbian identity development; families; psychosocial impact of AIDS; availability and utilization of health services by lesbian and gay populations. Defining a population of lesbians and gay men; sampling problems; the effect of bias in lesbian/gay research on internal validity and generalizability of research results.

course.course_name: Globalization, Social Movements and Community Health
course.course_description: Overview of the most important social, cultural, political, and economic transformations taking place late 20th and early 21st century, and the implications of these changes for community health in major urban centers in the U.S. and abroad. Multiple dimensions of globalization and the impact on the development of new social movements at the community level. Examines the ways in which processes associated with globalization, such as growing disparities in income distribution and the disappearance of work for major sectors of the urban population, impact upon community health problems. Community mobilization, advocacy and activism.

course.course_name: Coping With Chronic Illness and Disability
course.course_description: Reviews models of coping and psychosocial adaptation to chronic illness and disability. Focus on the adaptive tasks (e.g., identity reconstruction, stigma management, adherence to treatment regimens, symptom management) posed by these conditions and various coping strategies. Factors (e.g., sociocultural beliefs, illness representations or schema, social support) that influence individuals' accommodation to chronic illness and disability, opportunities for stress-related growth and benefit finding among those living with chronic illness and patients' perspectives on their lived experience with chronic illness examined.

course.course_name: Caregiving In Chronic Illness: Psychosocial Perspectives
course.course_description: Examines the care provision role of the family and the primary network in contemporary society, tracing the historical, developmental and economic changes in the informal care. Analytic and empirical insights on care provision in chronic diseases of adulthood such as Alzheimer's/dementia, cancer and AIDS/HIV and theoretical models of informal caregiving analyzed.

course.course_name: Social and Economic Determinants of Health
course.course_description: Disparities in health and illness related to social and economic inequality in the U.S. Theoretical and empirical research on factors linked to class, income, education and ethnic differences that have been hypothesized to explain the generally poorer health and higher rates of mortality among members of lower socioeconomic groups. Concepts and measurement of health and social stratification, assessment of evidence for proposed links between socioeconomic position and health through group differences in health beliefs, health behaviors, exposure to social stress, occupational hazards and employment instability, and access and utilization of medical care services.

course.course_name: Health Promotion, Disease Prevention and the State: Ethical and Political Controversies In Public Health
course.course_description: The political and ethical dimensions of public health policy; issues of justice and liberty; the prevention of diseases associated with personal behavior, protection against occupational hazard, epidemic control, and access to health care.

course.course_name: Immigrant Health In the U.S.
course.course_description: Current immigrant health and populations in the U.S. and N.Y.C. and the challenges to providing health care. Immigrant status (i.e., documented, undocumented, refugee, migrant) and health, cultural influences in health outcomes, acculturation/assimilation (stress), access to health care, and multicultural approaches to health promotion.

course.course_name: Race and Health
course.course_description: Health issues pertaining to black Americans and other minority groups. The concepts of health and illness and epidemiological studies of the differential rates of health disorders among minorities in comparison with whites.
course.prerequisites: core courses in epidemiology, biostatistics, and sociomedical sciences, and the instructor's permission.

course.course_name: Population Aging and Public Policy In Developing Countries
course.course_description: This course will offer an opportunity to students, both from the developed and developing countries, to acquire knowledge and understanding of the rapidly changing age structures, its consequences on economic and social policies, and the conditions of the older persons. Each student is expected to prepare a substantive paper on a selected aspect of population aging in a particular developing country, or a sub-region of developing countries. In light of the UN estimate that by 2050 there will be two billion persons aged 60 years and over and that about 80 percent of them will be living in developing countries.

course.course_name: Tobacco and Public Health: From Colonial Cash Crop To Global Epidemic
course.course_description: Nearly forty years since the first Surgeon General Report (Terry 1964) connecting tobacco use with cancer, tobacco remains the number one preventable death in the United States and in most developed countries. If current trends continue tobacco use will soon be the number one cause of preventable disease worldwide.  Tobacco control is a model for interdisciplinary study in public health and effective methods for approaching a major cause of death and disability through multilevel interventions including policy regulation. This course will explore multiple dimensions of tobacco use; health, social, and economic implications as well as the ethical, legal and scientific debates that have accompanied the development of tobacco control policies in the U.S.  In addition to giving students a thorough grounding in the area of tobacco and health, the course should provide students with an excellent basis for analyzing the various dimensions of other major public health problems.  The format will entail one hour or less of lecture with the remaining time spent in active discussion and debate.

course.course_name: Current Issues In Latino Health
course.course_description: Overview of mental and physical health issues of Latino populations in the U.S. Topics include the heterogeneity of Latino groups, health behavior theories, acculturation and identity theory, immigration, HIV/AIDS, cancer, coping, social support, and psychosocial adaptation to chronic illness. Analyzes dominant theories in health psychology behavioral medicine. Students learn to describe the health status and sociodemographic profiles of Latino groups, the major theoretical paradigms in Latino mental and physical health of Latino populations.

course.course_name: History of Public Health Decline In Harlem, 1950-1990
course.course_description: This course will focus on the synergism of housing destruction and public health decline that drove community disintegration in Harlem during the latter half of the twentieth century using vital statistics, census data, police and fire records, secondary histories, oral histories, and newspaper, magazine, and scientific journal articles. Employs both qualitative and quantitative methodology. Vital statistics, census data, police and fire records, secondary histories, oral histories, and newspaper, magazine, and scientific journal articles will be used. Slides and field trips will augment lectures. Students will be evaluated based upon class participation and attendance and a thirty-page paper. This paper will be written in an iterative process to ensure that students receive adequate feedback, in particular methodological support

course.course_name: Introduction To Medical Anthropology
course.course_description: Required for all sociomedical sciences students; open to others with the instructor’s permission. Overview of medical anthropology, the examination of health, disease, and medicine in the context of human culture. Cross-cultural data and comparative method. Ecological influence on health and disease; adaptation; subsistence and social structure, medical systems and theories; curing, patients and healers; diagnosis and divination; cognition; acculturation and social change.

course.course_name: Tobacco Control In the United States: the Legal, Ethical and Policy Debate
course.course_description: Explores the ethical, legal and scientific debates that have accompanied the development of tobacco control policies in the United States. After reviewing the history of tobacco and cigarette smoking in the U.S., four broad areas of tobacco control will be examined: restrictions on advertising, regulation of smoking in public spaces, taxes on products, and litigation. Will conclude with a brief look at tobacco control in international contexts.

course.course_name: Current Readings In Medical Anthropology
course.course_description: Analysis of a selection of new articles, books and controversies focusing on culture and health. Ethnography, theory, method, and policy.

course.course_name: Advanced Seminar On Theory and Research In Interpersonal Violence
course.course_description: Definitions, patterns, and explanations of interpersonal violence, and contemporary methods of violence research. The epidemiology of violence, research methods, comparative studies, several levels of explanation and theory, violence prevention and control.

course.course_name: Tobacco Seminar Series: an Unfiltered View
course.course_points_notes: Class will meet every other week.
course.course_points_cooked: 1 pt. Class will meet every other week.
course.course_description: This course is a stepping stone to further study and train in the development, implementation and evaluation of science-based, multi-level interventions for tobacco control in partnership with priority population communities and state/local health departments. Tobacco control is a model for interdisciplinary study in public health by linking various areas such as law, community organizations, medical and dental communities, counter-advertising strategies, youth prevention, taxation, and regulatory policy. Develops knowledge and skill base in its participants for addressing tobacco control issues and conceptualizing new models of research and practice.

course.course_name: Medical Anthropology: Advanced Seminar
course.course_description: Analysis of recent work in medical anthropology. Emphasis on complex society; the relationship between health, illness, and the larger cultural context; and the use of qualitative and quantitative methods; developments in theory and method.
course.prerequisites: Public Health P8755 or equivalent course or experience and instructors permission

course.course_name: Chronic Disease and Community Health
course.course_description: Chronic diseases are the most preventable of all health problems, yet they account for approximately 70% of annual deaths in the United States.  In fact, more than 90 million Americans live with such chronic conditions as, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, or cancer, and more than 25 million people experience major limitations in activity due to chronic illnesses.  Although rural and suburban populations face serious health problems, research clearly shows that urban populations, especially low-income residents of cities bear a disproportionate burden of ill health related to chronic diseases.  Rates of such diverse conditions as asthma, substance abuse and AIDS are higher in urban than non-urban areas.  Will present students with an overview of chronic diseases and their impact on urban neighborhoods.  Specifically, students will gain knowledge in the following areas: 1) chronic disease epidemiology, 2) lifestyle and behavioral risk factors, and 3) planning and implementing health promotion programs to reduce the social and economic burden of chronic diseases.  The goal is to help students understand the potential burden of chronic illnesses and to critically examine interventions and health promotion programs targeting urban populations.  Students will be exposed to various professionals working in chronic disease research and clinical practice.  The course will also utilize information and resources provided by the Guide to Community Preventive Services. This series of  documents provides evidence based recommendations to public health practitioners for community prevention services. This is a federally sponsored initiative that provides a systematic review of interventions designed to change risk behavior and reduce diseases.  Students will be expected to use the guide and course readings to supplement in-class material.
course.prerequisites: P6400 Epidemiology and 6700 Introduction to Sociomedical Sciences

course.course_name: Stigma, Prejudice, and Discrimination as Social Stressors
course.course_description: Explores the impact of stress and identity on health. This seminar engages students in critically examining relevant theory and research in stress, identity and health. Topics include: theoretical perspective and research evidence on the role of stress in health; concepts of self and identity; identity structure and identity development; health outcomes of stigma and prejudice; coping with stigma – the costs and benefits of concealing stigma; the experience of stigma and prejudice in social spaces; the intersection of stress and identity. Classes combine lecture and student discussions and presentations.

course.course_name: Decision Analysis: Making Decisions In Public Health and Medicine
course.course_description: Introduces students to the methods and range of applications of decision analysis in health care technology assessment, medical decision making, and health resource allocation. Objectives are: 1) to provide technical understanding of methods used, 2) to give students an appreciation of the practical problems of applying these methods in the evaluation of medical procedures, technologies and policies, 3) to give students an appreciation of the uses and limitations of these methods in decision making at the levels of national policy, health care organizations including hospitals and health maintenance organizations, and individual patient care, and 4) to give students the opportunity to apply the methods learned to a project and topic of their choosing.
course.prerequisites: An introductory course in probability and statistics. Introductory economics recommended but not required.

course.course_name: Health Psychology and Public Health
course.course_description: Conceptual and theoretical issues and research methods in the social psychological study of health. The field of health psychology and a review of convergences and distinctions from public health. The tension between individual (micro) and social environmental (macro) perspectives. Mind/body and health, conceptual issues and evidence for pathophysiological paths between the nervous system and the endocrine and immune system; stress in disease etiology; personality in disease etiology; ameliorating factors in stress, such as coping, resilient personality, and social support; the psychology of illness processes, such as doctor-patient interaction, and coping with disease; theoretical models of health promotion and disease prevention; and incorporating a bio-psychosocial model of health and illness. Case studies on environmental health issues, women's health and HIV/AIDS.

course.course_name: Community-Based Participatory Research In Public Health
course.course_description: Community-Based Participatory Research (CBPR) has received growing attention over the past several decades as international, domestic, funding agencies and researchers have renewed a focus on an approach to health that recognizes the importance of social, political and economic systems to health behaviors and outcomes.  The importance of this approach is reflected in the recent IOM report that CBPR which indicates that CBPR is one of the eight priority areas for improving the public health.  CBPR is not a method but a system of investigation that involves the active collaboration of the potential beneficiaries and recognizes and values the contributions that community-based participatory research can make to new knowledge and to the translation of research findings into public health practice and policy. CBPR as it is often referred is a collaborative approach to research that recognizes the value of equitably involving the intended beneficiaries throughout all phases of program planning, implementation and evaluation.
course.prerequisites: Good Clinical Practices Certificate Exam; also 6727 and 8772

course.course_name: Planning and Implementing Health Promotion Programs
course.course_description: Most health promotion programs fail, often because their design is based on precedent, tradition or intuition, rather than on health behavior theory and research.  Students in this course will learn and practice a comprehensive , theory-and evidence-based approach to designing multilevel, community-based health programs that can substantially improve the success of public health programs.
course.prerequisites: Biostatistics and Epidemiology core courses and P6727, Preventive Health Behavior; and instructors permission. Students registering in this course should have an elementary understanding of needs assessment and the use of health behavior theory for program planning.

course.course_name: A Social History of American Public Health
course.course_description: The role public health practice has played in American history during the 19th and 20th centuries. The social/biological environment and the creation of conditions for 19th- century epidemics of cholera, typhoid, yellow fever and other epidemic diseases. The changing urban and industrial infrastructure and their relationship to late 19th- and 20th-century concerns about tuberculosis, industrial illness and infection. Public health practice and campaigns. Social attitudes towards the industrial worker, the immigrant, and the urban environment. Boundaries between public health and medical practice and their shifting definitions. Changes in urban living and culture through the transformation of the industrial work place.

course.course_name: Introduction To Sociomedical Sciences Research Methods
course.course_description: Overview of fundamental concepts and components of research methodology as used for social science investigation of public health issues. Focus on quantitative and qualitative research methods and different types of research designs, development of data collection instruments, data collection techniques and the statistical analysis of data (all components involved in sound public health research).

course.course_name: Survey Research Methods
course.course_description: Overview of methods and practical skills in survey research. Defining the aims of a survey, sampling, question-wording and designing ths survey instrument, methods of data collection (including face-to-face and telephone interviewing and mail questionnaire), entry of data, elementary data analysis, writing the report, and ethical issues.

course.course_name: Public Health Informatics
course.course_description: An overview of the field of public health informatics, combining perspectives from public health, computer science, and social and behavioral science.  Provides an overview of the needs and uses of information in public health, covering specific applications and general methods, current issues, capabilities and limitations of public health informatics.

course.course_name: Community Health Development: Linking Services, Training, Research and Activism
course.course_description: Draws on the instructor's work around inter-and intra-agency system building efforts and linkages between an academic center and community-based agencies and networks in high-risk neighborhoods. The confluence of poverty, AIDS, tuberculosis, substance abuse and violence in inner city neighborhoods makes them key sites for studying the underlying causes of disease and approaches to their prevention and management.  East Harlem, the predominantly Latino and black inner-city neighborhood served by the Mount Sinai Center, provides such a stategic setting.  Objectives: to (1) provide theoretical underpinnings re: community development; (2) operationalize the blueprint by enumerating the corolaries to this framework and demontrating how they have been applied over the last six years; (3) identify and explore social science methods.

course.course_name: Critical Analysis: A Sociomedical Sciences Journal Club
course.course_description: Offered every other week. Develops skills to critically analyze journal research articles and the studies on which they are based.  Students critically review journal articles in their area of interest from an approved journal source list.  Specific learning objectives are to gain familiarity with journals across various disciplines relating to health behavior and health care needs and services; to identify the strengths and weaknesses of research studies by critically analyzing journal articles, specifically focusing on (1) sampling design, (2) conceptualization and measurement, (3) instrumentation, (4) reliability and validity issues and (5) limits of generalizability; and to experience the usefulness of regular journal reading.  Using a roundtable format, each session focuses on two journal articles selected by students.  On a rotating basis, students presentt a summary and a methodological critique of their selected journal article followed by class discussion of the analysis.  Requirements include oral presentation of the student's critical review of their selected journal article, attendance, participation in discussions, and a final written report, incorporating class critiques of the critical review presented orally.
course.course_instructors_expected: A. Aidala, J. Moon Howard, A. Brunswick
course.course_instructors_full: A. Aidala, A. Brunswick, J. Moon Howard

course.course_name: Qualitative Research Design In Public Health
course.course_description: Focuses on the principles and practices of designing social science research in public health, particularly using qualitative methodology. New issues for public health indicate a growing need for applied research, and social science research has become particularly important in the field of health promotion and in policy formation, evaluation and outcomes measurement. As a consequence, developing research agendas and undertaking research proposal assessment is becoming an important aspect of many health professionals' work. Principal research design concerns included in the course are: selecting a research topic; developing and clarifying specific research aims and purposes; selecting populations or target groups to be involved in the research; identifying audiences; assessing resources; nominating research outcomes and applications; project planning and data management; dissemination of findings. Key issues discussed include: capacities and objectives of qualitative social research; multi-method research; and the relationship between difficult health problems and feasible research projects, including collaboration with affected communities. Students  begin to develop their own research proposals during the course in preparation for subsequent intensive methods training in the second course in the sequence - P8786 Ethnographic Methods in Health Research.  The course utilizes case studies in qualitative research, particularly from the HIV/AIDS, sexual health and related fields. .

course.course_name: Ethnographic Methods In Health Research
course.course_description: Offers advanced training in the use of ethnographic methods in health research. Explores a range of different qualitative research methods, including participant observation, in-depth interviewing, oral histories, life histories, and case studies, and examines the ways in which these methods can be employed in developing ethnographic studies. Readings draw on different methodological texts and guidelines, as well as a range of published ethnographic studies of different health issues in order to illustrate the use of different approaches. Students are also expected to carry out hands-on observation and interviewing on a regular basis, and receive feedback from the instructor and other class participants on fieldnotes, analysis and interpretation of ethnographic data.

course.course_name: Theoretical Foundations of Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_description: This is the first part of a two-semester seminar which essays a selective genealogy of the major theoretical traditions undergirding contemporary practice in the sociomedical sciences. The historical review in the fall – like the critical examination of current research projects in the spring – is guideded  by the framing interests and signature emphases of the department: urban environs in transformation, social structures and axes of inequality, disparities in morbidity and mortality, agency and identity, social construction and production of health and disease, globalization and marginalization. The overall aim is to familiarize students with the relevant interpretive/analytic traditions, provide a rehearsal stage for testing out particular tools and frameworks in “compare and contrast” exercises, and build the theoretical foundations  enabling  them to critically assess contemporary work in the field through the pratical means of close readings, class discussion, and reflective writing.  The second part of this seminar is P8789, Contemporary Debates in Sociomedical Sciences.
course.course_instructors_expected: K. Hopper, R. Parker, P. Messeri
course.course_instructors_full: K. Hopper, P. Messeri, R. Parker

course.course_name: Contemporary Debates In Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_description: This course is the second part of a two-semester seminar that  essays a selective genealogy of the major theoretical traditions undergirding contemporary practice in the sociomedical sciences. The critical examination of current research projects in the spring- like the historical review in the fall - will be guided by the framing interests and signature emphases of the department: urban environs in transformation, social structures and axes of inequality, disparities in morbidity and morality, agency and identity, social construction and production of health and disease, globalization and marginalization. The overall aim is to familiarize students with the relevant interpretive/analytic traditions, provide a rehearsal stage for testing out particular tools and frameworks in "compare and contrast" exercises, and build the theoretical foundations that will enable them to critically assess contemporary work in the field. In this second part of the sequence, special emphasis will be given to research by faculty members in the department, as well as by others working in related frameworks.  Both theoretical and methodological approaches to the sociomedical sciences will be examined in seeking to develop and overview of contemporary debates in the field.  Close reading, class discussion, and reflective writing will be the practical means we employ.
course.prerequisites: P8788, Theoretical Foundations of Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_instructors_expected: A. Fairchild, K. Hopper, R. Parker
course.course_instructors_full: A. Fairchild, K. Hopper, P. Messeri, R. Parker

course.course_name: Tutorials In Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_description: Primarily for students who wish to acquire further knowledge and research skills in areas of special interest. Individual or small group reading tutorials or guided independent research.

course.course_name: Tutorial: Self-Help Alternatives To Biomedical Therapies
course.course_description: Hypnosis, relaxation, biofeedback, meditation, and other nonintrusive, behavioral therapies, stress-based illness and self-destructive behaviors, e.g., hypertension and cardiovascular disease, surgical pain, headaches, smoking, and over-eating. A one- or two-term tutorial: (1) the psychological, sociological, and anthropological aspects of these alternative therapies; (2) identifying commonalities and differences; (3)developing research strategies for exploring the clinical and preventive use of these therapeutic modalities.

course.course_name: Social and Policy Implications of Bioterrorism and Other Weapons of Mass Destruction
course.course_description: Designed to explore the social and policy implications of weapons of mass destruction (WMD), with a focus on bioterrorism. The class examines the impact of WMD on public health  from historical, cultural, health policy and legal  perspectives.  Integrates aspects of WMD within a broad social and public health context. Topics to be discussed include epidemiological surveillance, recognition, prevention, treatment, and public health considerations of mass casuality events, including triage, site management and remediation, and workforce surge capacity.  The legal and ethical aspects of quarantine, mass prophylaxis, and mass vaccination are also discussed.  More current topics, such as emergency planning at the individual and organizational level, including family emergency planning, business continuity planning, and local/state/federal communication, are also considered.  Aspects of risk communication are reviewed. Vulnerable populations (i.e., medically underserved, aging, homeless, chronically ill, etc.), and the risk and impact of WMDs with respect to these populations are discussed. Guest faculty lectures provide an interdisciplinary approach to the subject.  Source materials include a wide range of materials provided to the students along with resources for additional study. Participation  in class discussions on the topics assigned to them each week. Final term paper.

course.course_name: Social and Psychological Consequences of Institutional and Community Care
course.course_description: Third-party payers and insurance carriers; shorter length of hospital stay for most illnesses; the rehabilitative phase managed in the community setting. Effects of this change on illness course and outcome (recovery/rehabilitation) and on the family or others in the patient's social environment. The changing locus of health care delivery and implications for role definitions, staffing and organization of services and support programs.

course.course_name: Tutorial: Review of Issues and Research on Compliance With Therapeutic and Preventive Regimens
course.course_description: Readings and discussion of development of research project. Topics include concepts and methods in defining and measuring compliance, determinants of compliance, and strategies for improving compliance. Regimens refer to taking of medications, keeping appointments, carrying out preventive oral home care practices, dietary and other life style changes--smoking, drinking, exercise--recommended for disease prevention and health promotion.

course.course_name: Seminar In Research and Professional Development
course.course_points_notes: This course is offered primarily to Master's students in the Departments of Sociomedical Sciences and Epidemiology who have been accepted into the IMSD program.
course.course_points_cooked: 1 pt. This course is offered primarily to Master's students in the Departments of Sociomedical Sciences and Epidemiology who have been accepted into the IMSD program.
course.course_description: This bi-weekly seminar is offered primarily to and designed for master's  students in the Departments of Sociomedical Sciences and Epidemiology who have been accepted  into the Initiative for Minority Student Development (IMSD) program, an Education Project Grant sponsored by the National Institute of General Medical Sciences of the National Institutes of Health. The purpose of the IMSD program is to increase the number of under-represented minority students who pursue doctoral degrees or research careers in public health. Students in the IMSD program are required to take this 2-year seminar (1 credit per semester), and to participate in a research project with a faculty mentor. Topics addressed in the course include research, methodology, and statistics (RMS) workshops addressing issues in common to Sociomedical Sciences and Epidemiology, as well as workshops on professional and academic development (PAD) issues. Students will be given the opportunity to present their work in progress.  Graded on a pass/fail basis.

course.course_name: Research Grant Proposal Writing
course.course_description: In-depth workshop designed to give advanced students an opportunity to prepare their own fundable research proposal.  Each week students are introduced to a different step in the research grant applicatio process using the National Institutes of Health (NIH) format. In addition, each student becomes knowledgeable about specific program initiatives and priorities, the grant mechanisms relevant at each stage of a typical research career, and the importance of team playing in large research projects.  They also learn the importance of developing relationships with project officers and how the NIH peer review process works.  The class uses a similar process to constructively critique and rate one another's completed research proposals.

course.course_name: Seminar In Criminology
course.course_description: Structure of criminal law and the role that criminal law and social policy should play in society's response to antisocial behavior. Various theories of crime, from the classical criminology of the 1970s, exploring their philosophical assumptions, their policy implications for the criminal law, empirical studies and findings that arguably support or refute them, and their leading contemporary exponents. Contemporary issues such as homicide, drug crimes, and family violence examined.

course.course_name: History and Policy: the Uses of History
course.course_description: Considers the intersection of history and policy.  Using a variety of case studies, students learn to identify the different ways history is used and abused in the policy arena.  Each case study underscores the ways in which history shapes and is shaped by policy. In exploring this dynamic link between history and policy, students learn to use history to comment on policy and to use current policy dilemmas to rethink history.
course.prerequisites: P8716, P8773, G8732 and instructors permission

course.course_name: Advanced Research Methods and Analysis
course.course_description: An advanced seminar for doctoral students in public health and the social sciences. The course objective is to provide students with instruction and hands-on experience in applying methods of quantitative analysis to research problems in social sciences with an emphasis on public health, health care and health behaviors.Topics covered include formulation of research questions and hypotheses, issues in complex sample design, measurement of variables, specification and estimation of single equations and systems of simultaneous equations to model casual relationships. Combines didactic lectures and active participation of students in computer labs and class presentations. Requirements center on analysis of a single data base provided by instructors. Students devise a research study and work in small groups to investigate the problem with the class  data base.

course.course_name: Tutorials In Sociomedical Sciences
course.course_description: Primarily for students who wish to acquire further knowledge and research skills in areas of special interest. Individual or small group reading tutorials or guided independent research.
